Color coding

For this diagrams we use the definition of an emotion in the two-dimensional coordinate system of valence and arousal. An emotion e is therefore a vector, like the one marked in the graph, e = (v, a) = (0.3, 0.4) .

To define a color coding for emotions and provide easy-to-read visualisations of learning data with associated emotions, we chose four colors:

for positive valence and positive arousal
for negative valence and positive arousal
for negative valence and negative arousal
for positive valence and negative arousal

The saturation indicates the distance from mean valence and arousal values. Then, both axes rely each on its own color property.
Valence goes from darker colors

This coding follows some of the principles revealed in:
Da Pos, O., & Green-Armytage, P. (2007), Facial expressions, colours and basic emotions. In Colour: Design and Creativity by The Society of Dyers and Colourists (UK), Vol 1.

Because the color codes rely on color properties (instead of concrete colors), the proposed visualisations allow alternative codings to fit corporate styling needs, like for example:

For every point its color is defined by its polar coordinates e = (r, φ) .

Time lines of distinct moods

Example: In the beginning of a learning session, the mood was rather negative, but later it got better, more positive and calm.

Bar charts of distinct moods

Example 2: The chart of moods relations with average performance in quizzes per topic shows, that when having most of the time a high arousal, the user reaches a better performance.

Scatterplot of performance in emotions

Example: Most dark dots of good performance gather in two different emotional areas: around mid level arousal and valence, and at higher arousal with a bit positive mood.

Time, performance and most frequently occuring emotion in a spie chart

Example 1: On two topics this user spends much time but still gets a low performance in quizzes, having low arousal moods.

Example 2: This user behaves differently, spending in a good mood less time on a topic and performing worse.
